pullRequest.body:
Both strong versions (p and q agree below some x) and weak (p and q agree everywhere)

helper for not juggling generalize_proofs


---

#### Declarations diff

`+ find_congr'`
`+ find_mono_of_le`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

:v: pechersky can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

> I claim that actually `generalize_proofs` probably was never needed, and `simp_rw` would have worked fine; but I don't know your original use case.

You're right:
```
import Mathlib

attribute [local instance] PiNat.metricSpace

open PiNat

lemma foo (x y c : â„• â†’ â„•) : firstDiff (x + c) (y + c) = firstDiff x y := by
  rw [firstDiff, firstDiff]
  rcases eq_or_ne x y with rfl|h
  Â· simp
  rw [dif_pos, dif_pos h]
  Â· congr -- you were right
    simp
  -- another option now
  -- Â· convert Nat.find_congr' _
  --   simp
  Â· simp [h]

lemma bar (x y c : â„• â†’ â„•) : dist (x + c) (y + c) = dist x y := by
  rcases eq_or_ne x y with rfl|h
  Â· simp
  rw [dist_eq_of_ne, dist_eq_of_ne h]
  Â· simp [foo]
  Â· simp [h]
```
bors r+

Please update the PR description.

I claim that actually `generalize_proofs` probably was never needed, and `simp_rw` would have worked fine; but I don't know your original use case.

Thanks, this seems reasonable.

maintainer merge

Thanks, this seems reasonable.

maintainer merge

The declaration itself looks reasonable otherwise. Thanks!

bors d+

Please update the PR description.

I claim that actually `generalize_proofs` probably was never needed, and `simp_rw` would have worked fine; but I don't know your original use case.

Is there a difference with simply writing:
```suggestion
lemma find_congr [DecidablePred q] {hp : âˆƒ n, p n} {hq : âˆƒ n, q n} (hpq : âˆ€ {n}, p n â†” q n) :
```
Also, should this be tagged `@[congr]`?

I had it written with `variable in` since that's what the lemma above looked like:
```
variable [DecidablePred q] in
lemma find_mono (h : âˆ€ n, q n â†’ p n) {hp : âˆƒ n, p n} {hq : âˆƒ n, q n} : Nat.find hp â‰¤ Nat.find hq :=
  Nat.find_min' _ (h _ (Nat.find_spec hq))
```

With or without `@[congr`], usage looks the same when using the `congr` tactic. I don't think I understand what `@[congr]` is for.
```
example [DecidablePred q] {hp : âˆƒ n, p n} {hq : âˆƒ n, q n} (hpq : âˆ€ {n}, p n â†” q n) :
    Nat.find hp = Nat.find hq := by
  congr
  guard_target = p = q
  ext
  exact hpq
```

> I don't think I understand what @[congr] is for.

To be honest, after trying out a few things I'm not too sure either. I suppose we'll do without `@[congr]` then!

I'm not sure this is useful; it's just
```lean
lemma find_congr [DecidablePred q] {hp : âˆƒ n, p n} {hq : âˆƒ n, q n} (hpq : âˆ€ {n}, p n â†” q n) :
    Nat.find hp = Nat.find hq := by
  congr!
  ext
  apply hpq
```
or
```lean
lemma find_congr [DecidablePred q] {hp : âˆƒ n, p n} {hq : âˆƒ n, q n} (hpq : âˆ€ {n}, p n â†” q n) :
    Nat.find hp = Nat.find hq := by
  obtain rfl : p = q := funext fun _ => propext hpq
  congr
```

That is: this doesn't use any facts about `Nat.find`, and is just a standard result about `DecidablePred`.

Yes, that's true. Having the explicit lemma available by name helps deal with `Nat.find ... = Nat.find ...` goals without having to do `generalize_proofs` and having the intermediate `have`. Are you suggesting to change the body of the proof, or to remove the lemma entirely?

```suggestion
/-- A weak version of `Nat.find_congr`, requiring `p = q` everywhere. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- A weak version of `Nat.find_mono_of_le`, requiring `q` implies `p` everywhere.
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Data/Nat/Find): Nat.find_mono_of_le and Nat.find_congr
